sub_topic: Finding the Fourier series of a function with a periodic discontinuity
message_1: Consider the periodic function $f(x) = \begin{cases} 1, & \text{if } 0<x<\pi \\ -1, & \text{if } -\pi<x<0 \end{cases}$ Find the Fourier series of $f(x)$ for one period.
message_2:
To find the Fourier series of the given function, we first need to find the Fourier coefficients $a_n$ and $b_n$. Since the function is odd, we know that $a_n = 0$ for all $n$. Thus, we only need to find the $b_n$ coefficients.

The formula for $b_n$ is given by:

$$b_n = \frac{2}{\pi} \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} f(x) \sin(nx) dx$$

We can split the integral into two parts, one for the positive part of the function and one for the negative part:

$$b_n = \frac{2}{\pi} \left( \int_{-\pi}^{0} (-1) \sin(nx) dx + \int_{0}^{\pi} (1) \sin(nx) dx \right)$$

Now, we can solve the integrals:

$$b_n = \frac{2}{\pi} \left( \left[ \frac{\cos(nx)}{n} \right]_{-\pi}^0 - \left[ \frac{\cos(nx)}{n} \right]_{0}^{\pi} \right)$$

$$b_n = \frac{2}{\pi} \left( \left( \frac{\cos(0)}{n} - \frac{\cos(-n\pi)}{n} \right) - \left( \frac{\cos(n\pi)}{n} - \frac{\cos(0)}{n} \right) \right)$$

$$b_n = \frac{2}{\pi} \left( \frac{1}{n} - \frac{(-1)^n}{n} - \frac{(-1)^n}{n} + \frac{1}{n} \right)$$

$$b_n = \frac{2}{\pi} \left( \frac{2}{n} - 2\frac{(-1)^n}{n} \right)$$

$$b_n = \frac{4}{\pi} \left( \frac{1 - (-1)^n}{n} \right)$$

Now we can write the Fourier series for $f(x)$:

$$f(x) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} b_n \sin(nx) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{4}{\pi} \left( \frac{1 - (-1)^n}{n} \right) \sin(nx)$$
